block.p: The P.L.O. has caused a rift in the United States-led international coalition against Iraq by pressing ahead with a Security Council resolution condemning Israel. Washington has threatened to veto the measure.

Jerusalem's Old City was mostly calm because the authorities were careful not to repeat the mistake they made on Monday. That morning, too few policemen were on hand to control 3,000 angry Palestinians who threw rocks at Jews worshiping at the Western Wall.
U.S. is trying to avoid a council fight on Israel
Air Force halts gulf training flights
Key armored units reach Saudi soil
Only four embassies hold out in Kuwait as food dwindles

Protestant and Catholic leaders are beginning to raise moral questions about American policy in the Persian Gulf, edging away from the general support they voiced for it two months ago and opening up a gap with their Jewish counterparts.
Egypt vote issue: A new assembly?
Lebanon officially asks Syria for military help to oust Aoun

The Soviet Union seems suspended between two world views. One proposes a smooth transition from Marxist slogans to capitalist comforts. The other is based on life as it already is for most people: chaotic, irrational, impenetrable.
Thousands rally in Prague to denounce speech by Communist

An Indian tribe in Northern Quebec is worried that a proposal to build dams on the Great Whale River may mean an end to the hunting, trapping and fishing that have defined a way of life for 5,000 years.
A group of Cambodian dancers on tour in the U.S. should be interviewed by the Immigration and Naturalization Service to determine whether more of them may want to defect, the State Department said.
North Korea, seeking ties, frees Japanese sailors

A gaping hole in the ozone layer has again opened over Antarctica, and scientists reported that the depletion of ozone there seemed to be nearly as severe as it was in the worst previous years, 1987 and 1989.
Kientzheim Journal: In Alsace, a sprig of Japan takes root
The budget talks grew more complex as Congressional Democrats and Republicans pushed rival plans and conflicting statements at the White House added to the air of confusion.
Offstage on the budget: Tug-of-war over Bush
Iraq is odd ally of Pentagon budget
Sour view of Congress emerges from a survey
Washington Talk: Furor on Medicare cuts offers lesson
Washington at Work: Kemp struggles to keep H.U.D. going

The Chemical Banking Corporation announced a sharp cut in its stock dividend and a loss for the third quarter, joining a growing list of large banking companies whose problems with real estate loans have led to reduced payments to shareholders.

Prostitutes and drug addicts are being raped with increased frequency and brutality, but they rarely report the assaults, often disappear during an investigation or are disregarded by the criminal justice system.

The State of Missouri, which fought all the way to the Supreme Court to prevent the removal of a feeding tube from a comatose patient, has asked to be allowed to withdraw from new court proceedings on the case.

A vast environmental measure on the California ballot seems to be faltering. Three national leaders of the environmental movement declared that the state faced an environmental crisis and they began a grass-roots drive for the measure.
Senator gets Puerto Rican plea on referendum
Republican calls Democrat a liar in Texas race for governor
Court orders Klan to stop imitating ''Mister Rogers''
Chicago receives $40 million to make schools more public
Illinois Journal: An Irish name can spell election
A study of twins reared apart has come up with one of the highest estimates yet for the heritability of intelligence, as judged by test scores.
Experts say space junk may create peril by 2000
Soviet booster rocket explodes after liftoff
135-million-year-old bird turns out to have been a flier
Members of a state financial board urged Mayor Dinkins to act more swiftly to detail his plans for keeping New York City's budget balanced, participants in the meeting said.
Quiet for four years, board is child of crisis
As fiscal ills grow, Dinkins and unions prepare to talk
Cuomo warns the state is ''in for a period of pain''
Rinfret and Republicans join for a show of unity
Opposition to low-income housing in white neighborhoods in Yonkers remains so potent that banks, fearing picketing or boycotts, are balking at financing the construction.

New York City's recycling program is a costly disappointment that is unlikely to succeed unless residents significantly increase their recycling rate and labor practices are made more efficient, the Sanitation Department said.

A struggle for control of a park in the Bronx has enmeshed two groups of Irish-Americans. Running through their conflict are charges of questionable dealings by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
The fourth Bensonhurst murder trial ended in a mistrial after a juror suddenly screamed in court at the victim's father, claiming that he was staring at her.
Court rejects church effort to bar play as blasphemous
The House of Representatives overwhelmingly approved a bill that would extend the life of the National Endowment for the Arts for three years and leave judgments about obscenity to the courts.
Word and Image: ''Lucy'' by Jamaica Kincaid
Free speech and civil rights clash in racism trial
Anatole Broyard, a book critic and an editor at The Times
Still time for the Police Corps
A. M. Rosenthal: The poisoned stream
McGeorge Bundy: Keep our powder dry
Barry Lopez: Discovering the Americas, again
Robin Herman: My very small step for womankind
